metadata.title: The Transition from Shepherding to Fencing in Colonial Australia
metadata.journal_or_publisher: Department of Physical Geography, Macquarie University

relevance.topic: Labor displacement due to technological change
relevance.relevance: The study examines the transition from labor-intensive shepherding to capital-intensive fencing in colonial Australia, highlighting the technological, social, and economic changes that led to labor displacement.

dependent_variables.displaced: Shepherds were displaced as fencing became widespread.
dependent_variables.wage_changes: High wages during the gold rushes contributed to the transition.

text_fragments: The transition from shepherding to fencing in colonial Australia was a technological revolution replacing labour with capital.
qualitative_data.narrative_descriptions: The study describes the complex transition from shepherding to fencing, involving technological, social, and economic changes.

historical_context.economic_conditions: High demand for meat and high wages during the gold rushes.
historical_context.institutional_context: Legislative changes granting land tenure and reducing Aboriginal populations.

outcomes.main_findings: The transition to fencing led to significant labor displacement of shepherds, driven by technological, social, and economic changes.
outcomes.conclusions: Fencing replaced shepherding as a more efficient and capital-intensive method of managing sheep, driven by a combination of technological advancements and economic pressures.
